c74object.name: bach.pad
c74object.digest: Pad, loop or trim an llll
c74object.description: Pads, loops or trims an llll in order to match a given length.

inlet.digest: The llll to be padded or trimmed

objarg.name: output_length
objarg.description: The first integer argument sets the output length, i.e. the target length that the output llll must have.

objarg.name: padding_elements
objarg.description: The second argument sets the element used for padding (or elements, in "Loop" mode). This can be a single symbol or integer, such as 0 or foo, or a complex llll of size 1, such as [1 2 4], or - in "Loop" mode - any complex llll, from which the padding elements should be picked. Not setting this argument, or setting it as null forces bach.pad to repeat the elements of the incoming list (default).

method.name: bang
method.description: Returns the padding of the most recently received llll.

method.name: int
method.description: A non-negative integer in the second inlet sets the desired output length for padding or trimming.

method.name: llll
method.description:
In first inlet: the incoming llll is padded or trimmed (accorded to the attribute values), and the result is output from the outlet.
In second inlet: the incoming llll is converted into an int.
In third inlet: sets the padding element (or elements, for "Loop" mode). This can be a single symbol or integer, such as 0 or foo, or a complex llll of size 1, such as [1 2 4], or - in "Loop" mode - any complex llll, from which the padding elements should be picked. Setting null forces bach.pad to repeat the elements of the incoming list (default).

attribute.name: align
attribute.description:
Sets the alignment of the original llll within the padded llll.
- If alignment is 0 = Left (default), the padding will be done at right.
- If alignment is 1 = Center the padding will be equally done at left and at right (rounding to the right).
- If alignment is 2 = Right, the padding will be done at left.

attribute.name: loopsize
attribute.description: Sets the number of elements to be repeated in "Loop" mode (has no effect in "Repeat" mode)

attribute.name: mode
out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the following:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message. To keep the representation invertible (i.e., to allow a bach object receiving a text-format llll to interpret it exactly as if it was native format, except for the size limitation), some specific kinds of symbols are preceded by a backtick: namely, symbols containing parens, or containing textual representations of numbers or pitches, or beginning with a backtick, plus the symbols "null" and "nil" (distinct from the reserved words "null" and "nil" representing the empty list and the empty sublist) are preceded by a backtick. Moreover, the symbols "int", "float" or "list" are preceded by a backtick only if they are the first element of an llll, to distinguish them from the corresponding reserved messages of Max.
m: 'max' output: mostly equivalent to the "t" specifier, but no symbol is backticket except "int", "float" and "list" at the beginning of an llll. It is important to notice that, differently from text-format lllls proper, Max-format lllls might not be invertible even if they do not reach the size limit for Max message. This means that a bach object receiving a Max-format llll output from another bach object might interpret it differently from the original, or in some cases might even reject it.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.

attribute.name: roundalign
trim
attribute.description: If the trim attribute is set to 1 (default), when the output length is less than the length of the original llll, this latter is trimmed at output; otherwise it is output as it is.

c74object.discussion: If the required length is less than the original one, the llll can be trimmed, depending on the trim attribute.
